conclusion: To solve the problem of finding the work done externally by the gas from state A to state B, we need to follow these steps:
The process from point A to point B is a constant pressure process (isobaric process).
Point A has a volume \(V_A = 3 \text{ L}\) and Point B has a volume \(V_B = 4 \text{ L}\).

premise: Point A has a volume \(V_A = 3 \text{ L}\) and Point B has a volume \(V_B = 4 \text{ L}\).
conclusion: The change in volume \(\Delta V\) is given by \(\Delta V = V_B - V_A = 1 \text{ L}\).
The work \(W\) done on or by the gas during an isobaric process can be calculated using the formula: \(W = p \cdot \Delta V\).
Substitute the values into the formula: \(W = 1 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa} \times 1 \text{ L} = 1 \times 10^5 \text{ J}\).
Since the work done by the gas is the negative of the work done on the gas, the work done externally by the gas from state A to state B is \(W_{\text{external}} = -W\).

premise: The work done by the gas is the negative of the work done on the gas.
conclusion: The work done externally by the gas from state A to state B is \(W_{\text{external}} = -1 \times 10^5 \text{ J}\).
